citations.narrative:
The licensee does not have records of acquisition for the animals that were acquired since the previous inspection,
totaling 5 ducks.
Failure to maintain such records prevents tracing of animals and identification of trends in animal losses.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession.

The licensee's two wolf-dog hybrids did not receive the following prevention in accordance with their program of veterinary
care:
- "Vincent," an adult male, has still not been receiving the rabies or distemper vaccine "annually" as prescribed by the
program of veterinary care. The licensee's attending veterinarian was unable to administer the vaccines during the dogs'
annual exam on September 12, 2025, due to the dog's temperament. Records of Vincent's previous vaccinations could
not be located, but the licensee hypothesized it has been 2-3 years.
- Heartworm prevention: The licensee has not been administering heartworm prevention to the two dogs or two wolf-dog
hybrids. The licensee reported that he cannot remember when he stopped providing heartworm prevention for the dogs.
On September 12th, 2025, "Arctic," an adult male, tested positive for heartworms. Arctic since completed his course of
heartworm treatment according to the attending veterinarian and is currently otherwise in good health. The program of
veterinary care states that heartworm prevention shall be administered "according to recommendations and duration of
product".
Failure to follow your veterinarian's program of veterinary care can affect both animal and public health.
Correct by: Vaccinating all dogs in accordance with your program of veterinary care and providing preventatives in
accordance with your veterinarian's guidance. The program of veterinary care must include sampling and treatment of
parasites in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.

The facility's 12 ducks and 4 geese are not provided aquatic areas during the winter. The inspector observed several
wading pools frozen over and snow-filled during the inspection. The licensee stated he was not aware that the pools must
be available to the animals year-round.
Lack of appropriate aquatic areas prevent waterfowl from exhibiting species-specific behavior and can affect the birds'
overall physical and behavioral health.
Correct by: Providing an aquatic area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool. Pools must be of sufficient surface
area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing,
swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement.
Correction Date: December 31, 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a documented environmental enhancement plan for the birds at the facility. The inspector did
not observe any enrichment items in the enclosures housing the birds.
Environmental enhancement ensures that the birds may exhibit species-specific behaviors and helps prevent
psychological distress.
Correct by developing, documenting, and following a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement which
promotes the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in
accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate
professional journals or reference guides.
Correction date: December 31, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Two of the night shelters provided for the free-roaming birds (20 chickens, 12 ducks, and 4 geese) contained an
excessive accumulation of feces.
One of the shelters contained a layer of matted straw mixed with feces on the floor, making it difficult for the birds to avoid
their excreta in this shelter. In a second shelter, the inspector observed an area where the geese appeared to prefer
passing stool, leading to a mound of goose feces that appeared to be several days worth.
Allowing excreta to accumulate can be a disease hazard and attract pests and odors.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the birds contained in
the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correction date: December 20, 2025.

One of the ducks in the facility had significant feather loss on the back of the neck and along the back of the animal. The
licensee reported that this duck was being excessively mounted by other ducks and had intended to separate this duck
from the flock but had not yet done so.
Housing incompatible birds can lead to health effects such as stress, injuries, and lack of access to food and water.
Correct by separating the incompatible ducks and ensuring that birds are not housed with other animals, including
members of their own species, unless they are compatible and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and
by actual observations.
Correction Date: December 20, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee does not have records of acquisition for the animals that were acquired since the previous inspection, 
totaling 5 ducks.  
 
Failure to maintain such records prevents tracing of animals and identification of trends in animal losses. 
 
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession. 
3.13(a)(3)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee's two wolf-dog hybrids did not receive the following prevention in accordance with their program of veterinary 
care:  
- "Vincent," an adult male, has still not been receiving the rabies or distemper vaccine "annually" as prescribed by the 
program of veterinary care. The licensee's attending veterinarian was unable to administer the vaccines during the dogs' 
annual exam on September 12, 2025, due to the dog's temperament. Records of Vincent's previous vaccinations could 
not be located, but the licensee hypothesized it has been 2-3 years. 
- Heartworm prevention: The licensee has not been administering heartworm prevention to the two dogs or two wolf-dog 
hybrids. The licensee reported that he cannot remember when he stopped providing heartworm prevention for the dogs. 
On September 12th, 2025, "Arctic," an adult male, tested positive for heartworms. Arctic since completed his course of 
heartworm treatment according to the attending veterinarian and is currently otherwise in good health. The program of 
veterinary care states that heartworm prevention shall be administered "according to recommendations and duration of 
product". 
 
Failure to follow your veterinarian's program of veterinary care can affect both animal and public health.  
 
Correct by: Vaccinating all dogs in accordance with your program of veterinary care and providing preventatives in

accordance with your veterinarian's guidance. The program of veterinary care must include sampling and treatment of 
parasites in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The facility's 12 ducks and 4 geese are not provided aquatic areas during the winter. The inspector observed several 
wading pools frozen over and snow-filled during the inspection. The licensee stated he was not aware that the pools must 
be available to the animals year-round. 
 
Lack of appropriate aquatic areas prevent waterfowl from exhibiting species-specific behavior and can affect the birds' 
overall physical and behavioral health. 
 
Correct by: Providing an aquatic area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool. Pools must be of sufficient surface 
area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, 
swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement. 
 
Correction Date: December 31, 2025. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not have a documented environmental enhancement plan for the birds at the facility. The inspector did 
not observe any enrichment items in the enclosures housing the birds.  
 
Environmental enhancement ensures that the birds may exhibit species-specific behaviors and helps prevent 
psychological distress.  
 
Correct by developing, documenting, and following a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement which 
promotes the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in 
accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate 
professional journals or reference guides. 
 
Correction date: December 31, 2025. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Two of the night shelters provided for the free-roaming birds (20 chickens, 12 ducks, and 4 geese) contained an 
excessive accumulation of feces.  
 
One of the shelters contained a layer of matted straw mixed with feces on the floor, making it difficult for the birds to avoid 
their excreta in this shelter. In a second shelter, the inspector observed an area where the geese appeared to prefer 
passing stool, leading to a mound of goose feces that appeared to be several days worth.

Allowing excreta to accumulate can be a disease hazard and attract pests and odors.  
 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as 
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the birds contained in 
the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.  
 
Correction date: December 20, 2025. 
3.160(a) 
   
Compatibility and separation 
One of the ducks in the facility had significant feather loss on the back of the neck and along the back of the animal. The 
licensee reported that this duck was being excessively mounted by other ducks and had intended to separate this duck 
from the flock but had not yet done so.  
 
Housing incompatible birds can lead to health effects such as stress, injuries, and lack of access to food and water.  
 
Correct by separating the incompatible ducks and ensuring that birds are not housed with other animals, including 
members of their own species, unless they are compatible and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and 
by actual observations. 
 
Correction Date: December 20, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
